intro: Minuartia zarencznyi var. divestita, commonly known as the naked sandwort, is a low-growing, mat-forming perennial plant native to arctic and alpine regions. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers that typically bloom in shades of white or pale pink. The plant has succulent, fleshy leaves that help it retain moisture in harsh, cold environments. It thrives in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in high-altitude or polar regions. Its botanical structure is adapted to withstand extreme weather conditions, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
